chapter.title: 124 Fusarium and Other Opportunistic Hyaline Fungi

sect1.title: 124 Fusarium and Other Opportunistic Hyaline Fungi
sect1.para: SEAN X. ZHANG, KERRY O’DONNELL, NATHAN P. WIEDERHOLD, AND CONNIE F. CAÑETE-GIBAS

The opportunistic hyaline or lightly colored molds constitute a phylogenetically diverse group of common to rare fungi, some of which are only known to reproduce asexually while others possess sexual and asexual life cycles. These fungi typically occur as saprobes in soil, in air, or on plant litter or as facultative plant pathogens. Some may be recovered from patients without having any clinical significance. Others are isolated infrequently enough to challenge the proficiency of a diagnostic laboratory, and critical assessment is required to evaluate the significance of their recovery. While several of the genera treated in this chapter include species that have either lightly colored or dark (melanized) conidia, the emphasis is on those fungi that grow in tissue in the form of hyaline or lightly colored, septate hyphae.

The term “fusariosis” is used to define infections caused by species ofFusarium (1) (Table 1), but the practice of coining disease names based on the fungal genus is disadvantageous when infections are caused by uncommon or rare pathogens. The wide variety of fungi involved makes it difficult to place the organisms into accessible groups, and problems arise when fungal names are changed. To avoid unnecessary name changes for disease names based on a genus, two major disease groups have been proposed: hyalohyphomycosis and phaeohyphomycosis (2). Although the groups were defined as encompassing similar clinical spectra, they were distinguished by the presence of septate hyphae in tissue without (hyalohyphomycosis) or with (phaeohyphomycosis) pigmentation or melanin in the fungal cell wall. However, some fungi, such as Scedosporium species or Neoscytalidium dimidiatum (formerly Scytalidium dimidiatum) (3), which form darkly pigmented colonies and conidia in vitro, produce hyaline or lightly pigmented hyphae in tissue. Similarly, rare fusariosis cases have been reported to produce darkly pigmented colonies in vitro and in vivo (4). The Fontana-Masson stain helps to detect melanin pigmentation of fungal elements in tissue, but the results are not always conclusive (see also the discussion in Chapter 116 of this Manual). Some fungi with variable pigmentation may stain faintly or inconsistently. In practice, the terms for the disease categories have been used to designate infections caused by fungi that are either hyaline or pigmented (melanized, phaeoid, dematiaceous) in vitro. Although it may be useful to have terms for broad categories of mycotic diseases, there are problems in categorizing fungi by color. A subcommittee of the International Society for Human and Animal Mycology (ISHAM) has suggested that fungal diseases be named by providing a specific description of the pathology and naming the causative agent, e.g., “subcutaneous cyst caused by fungus X” (5, 6).

sect2.title: TAXONOMY AND IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: The opportunistic hyaline molds include an ever-increasing number of genera. Most do not produce a teleomorph (meiotic sexual stage) in culture and comprise taxa that are either anamorphs (mitotic asexual stage) of the Ascomycota and Basidiomycota, or genera for which no sexual state has been described (seechapter 117 of this Manual). Today the relationships between many anamorphs (conidial fungi) and their sexual relatives (teleomorphs) are known through discovery of a sexual cycle or are inferred by phylogenetic analysis of DNA sequence data. This knowledge is extremely important in understanding fungal relationships and has allowed placement of fungi that were thought to only reproduce asexually next to their sexual relatives in fungal phylogenies. Rapid developments in this area have focused on circumscribing monophyletic genera and on recognition of genealogically exclusive, phylogenetically distinct species, particularly among the fusaria (7–17). In species that are homothallic or self fertile (see chapter 117), completion of a sexual cycle in culture may be difficult to obtain without the use of specialized media and extended incubation. When dual nomenclature was abandoned on January 1, 2013 (18, 19), this allowed for the unitary use of the name Fusarium over various teleomorph names for their sexual states, such as Gibberella and Neocosmospora (20). Perithecial sexual states are not useful for the purpose of identification, in part because fewer than 10% are known to reproduce sexually. The majority of fusaria studied to date are presumed to be self sterile or heterothallic because PCR screens for mating type indicate that most possess only one of the two idiomorphs (i.e., MAT1-1 and MAT1-2) required for sexual reproduction (21)

Prior to the development of DNA sequence-based phylogenetic classification of medically important fungi over the past 3 decades, most of the pathogenic conidial molds considered in this chapter were classified in the artifical group Hyphomycetes because they were not known to produce a sexual state (22–24). Phenotypic identification of Hyphomycetes is based on morphology of the conidia and the mechanisms by which conidia are formed (conidiogenesis; see chapter 117). Three basic tools are necessary for practical observation of these features. (i) An ocular micrometer is essential for determining sizes of conidia or sexual spores when present. Identification of molds often requires comparison with published taxonomic descriptions in which size is often a key criterion for species distinction. (ii) A dissecting microscope with magnification of up to ×60 and basal illumination is useful for examining colonies in plates or tubes for the presence of conidia in chains or slimy heads, specialized structures such as Hülle cells, sclerotia, conidiomata, or sexual fruiting bodies formed on the colony surface, under aerial mycelium, or embedded in the agar. (iii) Microscopic mounts that allow observation of how a fungus forms conidia also are necessary. Slide culture preparations are excellent for many fungi, and generally necessary for those with small, delicate conidia (25, 26); however, rapidly growing species such as those in the genus Trichoderma should be examined early by tease or tape mounts (27). Morphologic features important for identification of conidial fungi include (i) conidium size, shape, and pattern of septation; (ii) color of conidia and conidiophore, whether light (hyaline) or dark (melanized or phaeoid); (iii) developmental aspects of conidiogenesis, including the nature of the conidiogenous cell; (iv) mechanism of conidium liberation or dehiscence; and (v) features of a multihyphal structure producing conidia (i.e., conidioma if present). Differences in conidial shape and septation are useful characters for preliminary distinction and have been used traditionally for grouping conidial fungi.

Conidia may be nonseptate or may have one or more septa. Some fungi produce septate and nonseptate conidia. In a genus such asFusarium, where large multiseptate and much smaller septate or nonseptate conidia are produced, they are referred to as macro- and microconidia, respectively. Conidia also vary in shape. Some macroconidia are long and narrow, as in Fusarium. Development of a conidium may occur by conversion of an existing cell or several cells (thallicarthric or arthrosporic) or may involve construction of a new wall or blowing out of a portion of a preexisting wall (blastic). Conidiogenesis usually occurs at a particular location on a conidiogenous cell. If development occurs at a site that remains fixed and gives rise to more than one conidium, then the site is referred to as stable or determinate. If conidia develop at new points on the conidiogenous cell (or axis), then the site is described as unstable or indeterminate. New sites may occur on an axis which lengthens (progressive) or shortens (retrogressive). Depending on the species, conidiogenous cells may produce a single conidium or multiple conidia. Sympodial development involves the development of a single conidium at each successive site, resulting in a geniculate conidiophore. Phialides and annellides are specialized conidiogenous cells that produce multiple conidia. Conidia may be produced successively (serially) and develop in slimy masses or in chains, with the youngest at the base of the chain (basipetal) or the youngest at the top of the chain (acropetal). Although it is sometimes difficult to differentiate between the two types of cells, the annellide elongates and sometimes narrows during formation of each new conidium, leaving an often imperceptible series of rings or scars on the conidiogenous cell, whereas the phialide usually does not elongate and sometimes forms a collarette on top of the conidiogenous cell. Scrutiny of the conidiogenous locus by use of an oil immersion objective may be necessary to make this distinction. Holoblastic conidiogenesis, in which the inner and outer cell walls are involved, usually results in the formation of acropetal chains. The distinction between acropetal and basipetal chains may be revealed by comparison of the size and wall morphologies of the distal and proximal conidia in the chain. The youngest conidium is recognizable by its smaller size, lighter color if the conidia are pigmented, and differences in wall ornamentation if the conidia are roughened. Some conidiogenous cells form multiple conidia simultaneously over the surface of the swollen cell. When mature, conidia detach by fission of a double septum (schizolytic dehiscence) or by lysis of a supporting cell (rhexolytic dehiscence). Lytic dehiscence typically occurs in the dermatophytes and other members of Onygenales.

The presence of different conidial states can make identification difficult. Careful examination and sometimes subculture via a single spore or hyphal tip are required to assess whether the conidial types represent different states of the same fungus or whether the isolate is contaminated with more than one species. Some molds produce more than one type of conidial state (i.e., synanamorphs). These may be represented by simple yeast or yeast-like stages or by the formation of complex conidiomatal structures such as sporodochia (conidiophores borne crowded on a compact mass of hyphae or a hyphal stroma), synnemata (conidiophores aggregated into a compound stalk), or pycnidia (conidiogenous cells formed inside a round or oval fruiting body). Production of synanamorphs may be influenced by the agar medium used and may be lost upon repeated subculture.

The number of hyaline fungal species that have been reported to cause opportunistic infections in humans and other animals is increasing, and it is beyond the scope of this chapter to describe them all. Some reports identify the fungus only to the genus level, while others provide the fungus name but without salient details of its colony and microscopic features. A continuing and vexing problem is that authenticity of published reports cannot be verified if the fungus is inadequately described and illustrated and if isolates are not deposited in publicly accessible culture collections. This chapter describes the salient colony and microscopic features of medically important species in the genusFusarium (Table 2) and other select hyaline opportunists (Table 3). Detailed descriptions of species listed are found in several reference manuals (15, 26, 28–37) as well as the current literature. Due to the rapid discovery of novel phylogenetically distinct species via multilocus sequence typing (MLST) over the past 25 years, many clinically important species were discovered, and most of these within F. solani and F. incarnatum-equiseti species complexes now have been formally named (38–40). In addition to NCBI GenBank (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/), FUSARIUM-ID v.3.0 is a downloadable resource for Fusarium species identification (41). Identifications are conducted via BLASTn searches of GenBank or FUSARIUM-ID using a partial translation elongation factor (TEF1) sequence, or portions of the DNA-directed RNA polymerase largest and second largest subunits (RPB1, RPB2) of the unknown as the query.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The spectrum of disease caused by hyaline molds is diverse. The disease is largely determined by the local and general immunologic and physiologic state of the host and may be symptomatic or asymptomatic. In most instances, the portal of entry for fungal propagules is likely via the lungs, sinus, or through a break in the epidermis due to trauma. Exceptions to this include introduction by means of contaminated surgical instruments, intraocular lenses, prosthetic devices, or other contaminated materials or solutions associated with surgery or routine health care. Individuals who have a severe debilitating disease or immunosuppressive therapy typically suffer from invasive pulmonary or paranasal sinus infections, but in some instances, the infecting fungus may spread to surrounding tissues or disseminate hematogenously to virtually any organ. Fungemia is uncommon except in disseminatedFusarium infections. Noninvasive forms of infection also have been noted in debilitated individuals as well as in individuals with apparently normal defense mechanisms. In such cases, the fungus colonizes a preexisting cavity in the lungs such as an ectatic bronchus, a tuberculous cavity, or a lung cyst. Other clinical syndromes usually occurring in immunocompetent individuals include chronic sinusitis, onychomycosis, subcutaneous abscess, keratitis, otomycosis, and allergic manifestations including bronchopulmonary mycosis and sinusitis in atopic patients.

Although the majority of saprobic and plant pathogenic molds are not considered pathogenic for humans and other animals and appear unlikely to be able to adapt to or take advantage of risk factors predisposing to opportunistic infection, those capable of growing at or near body temperature must be considered to have latent pathogenic capability. The diversity of fungi reported from human tissue has increased dramatically in recent years, concomitant with widespread species-level molecular systematic studies (28, 42, 43), as reflected by new reports of proven infection. Moreover, certain fungi are isolated often enough to be suspicious for pathogenic potential. Still, there is a need for definitive evidence of infection due to a normally saprobic mold. The laboratory procedure for confirming fungal etiology includes: (i) detection of hyphae in the specimen that are compatible with the morphology of the isolated mold; (ii) isolation of several colonies of the fungus or isolation of the same fungus from two or more specimens over time; (iii) accurate identification of the isolated mold; and (iv) confirmation of the mold’s ability to grow at or near body temperature. It should be noted here, however, that some species that fail to grow at 35°C are capable of inciting systemic disease in profoundly immunocompromised individuals (44) and are frequently agents of cutaneous/subcutaneous mycoses. Species of Fusarium or other hyaline molds isolated from deep tissue or body fluids must be considered potential invasive opportunistic pathogens. No fungal isolate should be discarded as a contaminant without thorough examination of the clinical specimen. Quality control measures are essential to ensure that isolation media are not contaminated (i.e., the fungus is growing from the specimen and not elsewhere on the agar medium). Close communication between microbiologists and physicians also is essential, especially for rare or unusual opportunists seen in individuals maintained on long-term immunosuppressive therapy.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Clinical specimens from patients with suspected mycoses should be collected aseptically and transported to and processed in the laboratory as soon as possible by using the standard procedures described inChapter 115 of this Manual. Because of the diverse clinical manifestations, various sites may need to be examined for fungal elements. Biopsy material, transtracheal aspirates, and sputum samples collected in the early morning all may be useful specimens for the isolation and detection of hyaline molds, as are infected nails. Swabs taken from mucous membranes and skin lesions are not recommended. Although the reliability in determining whether an isolate is a possible pathogen is increased if cultures of two different specimens yield the same organism, direct microscopic examination with a fluorescent brightener, histological examination, and culture of a tissue biopsy are more informative. Blood cultures are generally of limited use for detecting invasive hyaline molds that produce dry conidia (microconidia in chains) suited for air dispersal, such as Aspergillus (45), which rarely conidiate in vivo. However, Fusarium and other species that produce abundant yeast-like microconidia in wet masses, suited for water dispersal, can be disseminated hematogenically (46). For optimum recovery, the specimen should be inoculated onto several types of media and incubated at 28 to 30°C. Opportunistic molds are variably susceptible to cycloheximide, so media containing this selective agent should be used cautiously. Suspicious isolates, especially of uncommon species, should be tested for their ability to grow at 35 to 37°C. Potentially neurotropic species may also grow at 40°C and beyond (47, 48).

Colonies slow growing, growth enhanced at 37°C, initially white and yeast-like, becoming hyphal and buff with yellow reverse. Cycloheximide tolerant. Conidiophores dendritic (tree-like), bearing lateral branches. Arthroconidia formed by fragmentation of branches or from undifferentiated hyphae.
Compare withOnychocola, Scytalidium, Coprinellus, Coprinopsis, and Neoscytalidium.
Colonies gray centrally, yellowish-white at periphery. Polyphialides commonly present. Conidia in long, dry chains. Hyphae become dark brown, verrucose, and thick-walled with age.
Morphologically similar toAcremonium. Brunneomyces hominis only species in the genus with growth at 35°C.

Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidiogenous cells solitary, in whorls, or in sporodochia, basally swollen, proliferating sympodially at the tip in a zigzag (geniculate) fashion. Conidia one-celled, subglobose.
Compare withParengyodontium album and Sporothrix. Beauveria bassiana used for biological control of insects.
Colonies white to cream, restricted, heaped growth on PDA. Prefers alkaline conditions.C. albus differs from C. antarcticus in that it does not produce synnemata in culture.
Morphologically similar toAcremonium; conidia in slimy heads

Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidia one-celled, smooth to roughened, aleurioconidia sessile or at ends or on sides of unswollen stalks (Fig. 3C). Arthroconidia sometimes present (see Aphanoascus and Emmonsia).
Reports of infection by unnamed species are difficult to evaluate because isolates are not adequately described to confirm etiology.

Colonies white to salmon, moist or fasciculate (spiky), or tan, darkening to black in patches. Conidiogenous cells adelophialides (short, stumpy phialides without a basal septum), as well as awl-shaped phialides.Coniochaeta mutabilis forms brown chlamydospores, while C. hoffmannii does not.
Differs fromAcremonium by predominance of adelophialides. Hyphal elements usually reported as hyaline. Also see chapter 128.

Colonies fast growing, felty or cottony, yellowish-white, tan, orange or purple, sometimes with diffusing pigments. Conidiogenous cells awl-shaped phialides with a single opening, solitary, in branched structures or in sporodochia (conidiophores borne crowded in a compact mass of hyphae). Macroconidia straight or slightly curved with rounded ends, multicelled; microconidia not clearly distinguished from macroconidia. Chlamydospores sometimes present.
Distinguished fromFusarium by production of macroconidia with rounded apical cells and absence of foot cells

Colonies moderately fast growing, becoming olivaceous green or buff. Conidiogenous cells cylindrical phialides borne on verticillately or irregularly branched conidiophores formed on sporodochia. Conidia cylindrical, smooth, yellowish-green, forming in adherent columns. Irregularly shaped appressoria may be present.
Biological control agent for insects

entry.para: Differs fromChrysosporium by swollen stalks; conidia smooth at maturity.
Colonies moderately fast growing, yellowish-white, often zonate, powdery. Conidia formed at the ends of narrow stalks borne at right angles to fertile hyphae.
Differs fromChrysosporium by stalks borne at right angles.
Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidia one-celled, smooth to roughened, aleurioconidia sessile or at ends or on sides of unswollen stalks. Arthroconidia sometimes present.
Green iguana, inland bearded dragon, lizard, snake

Colonies restricted, raised, yellowish-white to grayish-white, cycloheximide tolerant (Fig. 3F). Conidia one- or two-celled cylindrical or swollen arthroconidia forming in adherent chains, detaching by schizolysis or lysis of thin-walled cells. Brown knobby setae often present (Fig. 3G).
Differs fromNeoscytalidium dimidiatum (see chapter 128), Coprinellus, and Coprinopsis by adherent chains, slow growth, and cycloheximide tolerance.

Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidia one-celled, smooth to roughened, aleurioconidia sessile or at tends or on sides of unswollen stalks. Arthroconidia sometimes present.
Emerging pathogen of captive and wild snakes

SectionPaecilomyces includes thermotolerant P. variotii and morphs of Byssochlamys and Thermoascus with fast-growing yellowish-brown, buff, or orange colonies (Fig. 3H). Phialides formed on verticillately branched condiophores. Conidia one-celled, in chains.
Thermoascus species also produce a Paecilomyces-like anamorph.
Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidia one-celled, smooth to roughened, aleurioconidia sessile or at ends or on sides of unswollen stalks. Arthroconidia sometimes present.
Northern tuatara, coastal bearded dragon, aquatic file snake

Colonies slow to moderately fast growing, yellowish-white. Conidiogenous cells solitary or borne in whorls, basally swollen, tapering at tip and proliferating sympodially in a zigzag (geniculate) fashion. Conidia one-celled, subglobose.
Colonies slow growing, white to grayish. Conidiogenous cells adelophialides, as well as awl-shaped phialides.P. obovatum produces a green diffusible pigment.
Compare withAcremonium and Coniochaeta. Also see chapter 128.
Slower growth than forPaecilomyces spp., maximum growth temperature 25–37°C, conidia lilac-colored (Fig. 4A), chlamydospores absent (Fig. 4B).

Colonies moderately fast growing with enhanced growth at 35°C. Cream to buff. Stipes and metulae rough. Cuneiform (wedge-shaped) to ellipsoidal conidia borne on rough-walled phialides lacking narrow necks as inPenicillium and Paecilomyces (Fig. 3D).
Syn.Penicillium argillaceum/Geosmithia argillacea. Compare conidia with those of Thermoascus (Paecilomyces) crustaceus.
Phylogenetically distinct fromAcremonium. Several species form ochre-brown colors on SDA. Conidiogenous cells adelophialides or long slender phialides.

Colonies fast growing, thermophilic (up to 50°C); cinnamon brown. One to three conidia formed on small denticles borne on sides or at ends of short, swollen stalks (Fig.3E). Conidia initially smooth and hyaline; brown and rough at maturity.
Colonies slow growing, yellowish-white to grayish (Fig. 4C); conidiogenous cells adelophialides and awl-shaped phialides.

Colonies fast growing, cottony or woolly, white becoming yellowish-green to dark green, sometimes with a yellow diffusing pigment (Fig. 4G). Conidiogenous cells flask-shaped or cylindrical phialides, single or in whorls; conidia green, smooth, ellipsoidal to subglobose (Fig. 4H).
TheT. longibrachiatum and T. harzianum clades both contain multiple species.

Colonies fast growing, woolly, tan to gray brown, occasionally greenish and sometimes with lavender shades, with honey-colored masses of conidia. Brown appressoria usually present; acervuli conidiomata, conidiogenous cells phialidic. Conidia hyaline, aseptate, straight to curved; also formed in aerial mycelium. Setae and sclerotia may be present.
Colonies may be darker with better sporulation on potato carrot agar. CompareC. dematium with Fusarium. Resolution of crytic species in progress.

Colonies pale to tan to gray-brown, woolly; pycnidial conidiomata, usually dark, separate or aggregated, ostioles single to several, immersed or semi-immersed, mostly thin-walled. Conidiogenous cells phialidic, conidia one-celled, small, hyaline, often guttulate.
Species-level identification difficult. New genera added for closely relatedPhoma-like species. See references 231 and 235. See chapter 128 for additional coelomycetous genera.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Fusarium species are ubiquitous soil saprobes and facultative plant pathogens that can cause infection or toxicosis in humans and other animals (15, 28, 49–51). They belong to the order Hypocreales, family Nectriaceae. Clinically significant species are mostly self sterile or heterothallic, with only the conidial or asexual state observed in culture. Prior to the abandonment of dual nomenclature on January 1, 2013, Fusarium sexual states were classified in Gibberella, Neocosmospora, and other genera; however, these taxa should be reported as Fusarium (20). Recently members of the F. solani species complex (FSSC) were erroneously described under the name Neocosmospora (52) because these authors mistakenly concluded that they were not part of a monophyletic Fusarium. However, based on comparative phylogenetic analyses of a 19-gene, 55.1-kb dataset that strongly supported a monophyletic Fusarium inclusive of the FSSC, the global clinical microbiological and phytopathological communities voiced nearly unaminous support for the unitary use of the name Fusarium for members of the FSSC and other early diverging lineages (38, 39). Unnecessary name changes of medically important fungi, such as renaming members of the FSSC as Neocosmospora based on the erroneous conclusion that they are not part of a monophyletic Fusarium (52), are strongly discouraged by the ISHAM Working Group on Nomenclature of Medical Fungi, to prevent nomenclatural instability (42). Based on the analysis of a few genes that suggested Aspergillus was non-monophyletic, a proposal was made to split the genus into multiple genera (53). This proposal was rejected by the International Commission of Penicillium and Aspergillus, which opted to accept the broad traditional circumscripton of Aspergillus to avoid name changes of these medically and biotechnologically important fungi. Recent comparative phylogenomic analyses strongly support Aspergillus monophyly (54) and suggest that the proposed segregation of multiple genera from Aspergillus was premature (53).

Several molecular phylogenetic studies have shown that fusaria once considered individual species by morphologic features are now known to represent species complexes (SCs) (7, 8, 14–17, 40, 55–58). Multilocus phylogenetic studies have revealed that the most frequently recovered clinically important fusaria are nested within the FSSC (Fig. 1A). This SC comprises over 110 phylogenetically distinct species within three major clades, with the human and veterinary isolates restricted to clade 3 (12, 38, 59). Most of the clinically important isolates are represented by three species that were initially designated groups 1 to 4 (8, 17, 60). Subsequently, more robust typing studies identified 34 species within clade 3 of the FSSC and indicated that groups 3 and 4 comprised one phylospecies now recognized as Fusarium falciforme (12). Because Latin binomials could not be applied to most of the species within clade 3 of this complex, species and multilocus haplotypes were distinguished by an ad hoc nomenclature using Arabic numbers and lowercase Roman letters, respectively (12). The most important clinically relevant species within the FSSC are Fusarium petroliphilum (FSSC 1), Fusarium keratoplasticum (FSSC 2) (61), F. falciforme (FSSC 3+4), Fusarium solani sensu stricto (FSSC 5) (62), and Fusarium lichenicola (FSSC 16). To date, 23 species within the FSSC have been reported to cause mycotic infections of humans and other animals (38). Although the Fusarium oxysporum SC (FOSC) is best known as an economically devastating group of vascular wilt pathogens on a wide range of agriculturally important plant hosts (63, 64), members of this genetically diverse complex of clonal lineages are some of the more common fusaria responsible for human disease (Fig. 1B). Multilocus sequence typing and AFLP analyses of over 100 isolates from the environment, hospital bronchoscopes, water sources, and clinical isolates identified a geographically widespread clonal lineage comprising >70% of isolates genotyped (14). These studies have further supported hospital water distribution systems as a potential source of health care-related infection (65, 66). Several medically important species are included within the species-rich Fusarium fujikuroi SC (FFSC) as defined by multilocus molecular phylogenetic analysis (7, 9, 10). These include F. verticillioides (Fig. 1C), F. proliferatum (Fig. 1D), F. napiforme, and F. nygamai. Another morphologically and phylogenetically diverse group of fusaria is the F. incarnatum-equiseti SC (FIESC) (11). The first multilocus phylogenetic analysis of this complex indicated that it comprised at least 28 species (13), but Latin binomials could be applied to only three of them with confidence (i.e., F. equiseti = FIESC 14, F. lacertarum = FIESC 4, and F. scirpi = FIESC 9). For this reason, an ad hoc informal nomenclature was developed for all of the species within this complex (13). Recent studies of this complex indicate that it comprises 44 species, most of which have been formally described (40). The F. chlamydosporum SC (FCSC) is also phylogenetically diverse and comprises at least eight species based on multilocus DNA analysis (13, 58). Similarly, the Fusarium dimerum species complex (FDSC) (Fig. 1E and F) currently contains seven named and two unnamed species (67). Colonies produced by members of the FDSC are unlike those in the aforementioned SCs in that they frequently show slower growth, and aerial mycelium is either absent or only sparsely developed, so colonies appear mucoid to slimy (usually some shade of orange). Moreover, they produce distinctive, predominantly two-celled crescent-shaped macroconidia.

sect1.title: Description of Agents
sect1.para: As can be seen from the taxonomic discussion, theFusarium species cited as etiologic agents of humans and other animals mostly fall within six SCs. Based upon our current understanding of the genus, the species most commonly associated with mycotic infections within these complexes are as follows: the FSSC includes F. falciforme, F. petroliphilum, F. keratoplasticum, F. solani (restricted to phylogenetic species FSSC 5), F. lichenicola, and 18 other species rarely associated with mycotic infections (38); the FOSC includes F. oxysporum, which comprises a large number of clonal lineages where sexual reproduction has not been observed; and within the FFSC, F. verticillioides, F. proliferatum, and F. thapsinum are the most important clinically relevant species, but several other species infect humans and other animals (68). Fusaria within three other SCs are rarely encountered in clinical laboratories. These include over 10 species within the FIESC that are rare mycotic agents (40); the FDSC with F. dimerum and F. delphinoides (67); and F. chlamydosporum and F. atrovinsoum within the FCSC (58).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: Numerous toxic secondary metabolites produced byFusarium species have been implicated in human disease, especially associated with the consumption of contaminated grain (see chapter 130) (69, 70). Alimentary toxic aleukia was described in individuals who consumed grain contaminated with trichothecene mycotoxins produced by F. sporotrichioides or F. poae (69). Besides orally ingested mycotoxins, systemic effects of exposure to inhaled mycotoxins, e.g., T-2 mycotoxins, have also been attributed to Fusarium, although these effects are poorly characterized (71). The more common clinical presentation in human disease is associated with fusarial conidia gaining access to the host, germinating, and subsequent tissue invasion by hyphae. The portal of entry, however, is unknown in most cases of invasive infection. Ingestion or access through mucosal membranes may occur in some (72, 73). Disseminated infection may also follow onychomycosis, often associated with cellulitis (74). Hospital water supply and distribution systems have also been implicated as a source of infection in immunocompromised patients by Anaissie et al. (65) and O’Donnell et al. (14). The most common mode of transmission, however, appears to be inhalation of airborne conidia (75, 76).

sect1.para: Although invasive infection byFusarium is uncommon, an increased incidence of disseminated infection has been reported in neutropenic patients with hematologic malignancy, in recipients of solid-organ transplants, and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) recipients (1, 46, 50, 73, 77–86). The incidence of fusariosis among allogeneic HSCT recipients varied between 4.21 to 5.0 cases per 1,000 in human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-matched related transplant recipients and 20.19 cases per 1,000 in HLA-mismatched transplant recipients (85). Among allogeneic HSCT recipients, a trimodal distribution was observed: a first peak before engraftment, a second peak at a median of 62 days after transplantation, and a third peak >1 year after transplantation. The actuarial survival was 13% (median, 13 days), with persistent neutropenia (hazard ratio of 5.43) and the use of corticosteroids (hazard ratio of 2.18) given to combat acute and chronic graft-versus-host disease being the most important factors associated with poor outcome (82, 85).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: Fusarium species can cause a spectrum of diseases in both healthy and immunocompromised hosts. A frequent infection in the normal host is keratitis resulting from trauma and penetration of the cornea, contamination of soft contact lenses and/or solutions (11, 60, 83, 87–89), or local immunosupression by corticosteroid drops (83). The keratitis outbreaks in Hong Kong (89), Singapore (88), and the United States (60) in 2005 and 2006 in contact lens wearers linked to use of ReNu with MoistureLoc Solution (Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, NY) resulted in the largest investigation and molecular characterization of fusarial keratitis isolates to date and clearly demonstrated that these strains occurred in nearly the full spectrum of clinically significant fusarial SCs. Other presentations in the immunocompetent host include those listed in Table 1. Cutaneous lesions in various stages of evolution (85, 90), fungemia (91), rhinocerebral involvement, pneumonia, endogenous endophthalmitis (92, 93), or combinations of these are common clinical findings in disseminated fusarial disease (46, 50, 73, 82–86, 94, 95). Unlike in invasive cases of aspergillosis, recovery of Fusarium species from the blood in disseminated disease approaches 60% (46, 84). Members of the FSSC account for approximately two-thirds of clinically relevant fusaria, with most cases involving keratitis resulting from trauma (28, 96). Although multiple species within the FSSC have been reported as F. solani, this name should only be applied to phylogenetic species FSSC 5 (62). Mayayo and colleagues (97) consider members of this SC to be the most virulent, and it has been suggested that their ability to produce cyclosporins may contribute to their pathogenicity (98). Members of the FOSC (14) and F. verticillioides (99) in the FFSC appear to be the next most common organisms recovered, with a similar spectrum of infection. F. verticillioides was the most frequently isolated species in deep-seated infections in Italy (100). Because the name F. moniliforme was used for F. verticillioides and several other species within the FFSC, the identity of the etiological agent reported under the former name in the older clinical case reports can only be verified by DNA typing of strains archived in culture collections. See the references for a more complete list of Fusarium species reported as etiologic agents of humans and other animals.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: Methods of collection, transport, and storage of specimens are detailed inChapter 115. Like invasive aspergillosis, invasive Fusarium infections are difficult to diagnose and usually require a combination of clinical, laboratory, and radiographic findings. However, unlike Aspergillus, Fusarium is more frequently recovered from blood, nails, and skin lesions of immunocompromised or immunosuppressed patients (72, 101). Recovery from a sterile site and microscopic evidence of invasive growth in tissue provide the most convincing evidence of invasive fusariosis.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: In direct examination of tissues, hyphae ofFusarium resemble those of Aspergillus, Paecilomyces, or Scedosporium species in size (3 to 6 μm in width), septation, branching pattern, and predilection for vascular invasion. Hyphae are irregular in width and may show areas of collapse. Hyphae exhibit both dichotomous branching (i.e., branching at 45°), as is commonly seen in invasive aspergillosis, and branching at right angles (102, 103). Microconidia and, rarely, macroconidia and phialides may be found in blood vessel lumens or in aerated tissues (103). Immunohistological methods may help to distinguish between infections caused by some hyaline molds, but cross-reactivity is problematic and serological tests are not in common use (104). Definitive diagnosis requires isolation and identification of the fungus, along with demonstration of fungal elements in tissue.

sect2.title: Antigen Detection
sect2.para: No commercial system is available for detection of genus-specific or species-specific antigens released byFusarium species in human infection. The diagnostic utility of polyclonal fluorescent-antibody reagents to members of the F. solani species complex in tissue sections from patients with invasive fusariosis was evaluated, but extensive cross-staining was observed with sections containing aspergilli, Purpureocillium lilacinum, and Scedosporium boydii (105).

There is one report that describes 9 out of 11 hematological patients with disseminated or deep-seatedFusarium infections who had repeated serum positive reactions with the Platelia Aspergillus galactomannan (GM) enzyme-linked immunosorbent (EIA) assay (Bio-Rad, Marne-La-Coquette, France) in the absence of Aspergillus spp. (106). Exoantigen extracted from Fusarium species including F. oxysporum, F. proliferatum, F. falciforme, and F. verticillioides produced positive reactions when tested undiluted by the GM EIA assay in vitro (106), suggesting that Fusarium species may produce an exoantigen that is cross-reactive with the Platelia Aspergillus assay. Antigens prepared from F. verticillioides were also found to cause borderline cross-reactivity with the Platelia Candida antigen assay (Bio-Rad) (107). This reactivity appeared to be specific for F. verticillioides, since extracts prepared from members of the F. solani and F. oxysporum species complexes showed no cross-reactivity in vitro.

Although (1→3)-β-D-glucan is not immunogenic, it is an important cell wall polysaccharide in most fungi that can be detected in serum via activation of a β-D-glucan-sensitive proteolytic coagulation cascade. Circulating (1→3)-β-D-glucan can be detected in the blood of patients with Fusarium fungemia and pneumonia (108, 109), although the presence of this marker is not specific for Fusarium or other hyaline molds (110). The sensitivity for detection of Fusarium infection was found to be 100% at a cutoff value of 60 pg/ml among three patients with invasive fusariosis (109). The clinical experience of (1→3)-β-D-glucan detection in patients with invasive fusariosis is limited, but the test is of value for patients with suspicion of invasive fungal infection as part of the diagnostic workup. In a mouse model, (1→3)-β-D-glucan remains high throughout the infection, suggesting that this marker may provide a specific and sensitive diagnostic tool for detecting invasive fusariosis (111). False-positive reactions of (1→3)-β-D-glucan are known to occur in some patients. These include subjects who had experienced renal failure and who were undergoing hemodialysis with cellulose membranes (112), subjects treated with certain immunoglobulin products (113), and specimens (or subjects) exposed to glucan-containing gauze or related materials (114). This underscores the need to combine (1→3)-β-D-glucan monitoring with clinical examination of the patient and other diagnostic procedures, such as high-resolution computed tomography scans, when making a diagnosis.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection Techniques
sect2.para: While most fusaria can be identified as members of this genus by experienced medical technologists utilizing microscopic and macroscopic features, accurate identification of most isolates to the species level requires DNA sequence data from portions of one or more phylogenetically informative protein-coding genes (TEF1, RPB1, and RPB2). These can be used to conduct BLASTn queries of NCBI Genbank (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nucleotide/) and FUSARIUM-ID v.3.0 to identify unknown isolates (41, 115). However, only a limited number of molecular diagnostic assays have been developed for medically important fusaria. In one study using PCR, Fusarium DNA was detected in tissues in a mouse model of disseminated fusariosis (116). In another study, a panfungal PCR was designed based on the 18S rRNA gene sequence and applied to ocular specimens from three patients with suspected bacterial or fungal endophthalmitis. Although Fusarium was detected in spiked specimens, no clinical samples from patients with Fusarium endophthalmitis were analyzed (117). PCR-based identification was also applied to Fusarium isolates obtained from patients with onychomycosis (118). Fusarium DNA was also detected in patients’ formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue samples with histopathology results using real-time quantitative PCR assays (119). The Fusarium species identified were the same as those known to cause disseminated fusariosis in immunocompromised patients.

Panfungal PCR systems that detect a wide range of fungi, includingFusarium, have been developed. In one study the PCR was positive with blood samples from a patient with invasive fusariosis and blood cultures positive for members of the FSSC (120). Luminex microbead hybridization technology, using 75 genus-specific hybridization probes, has recently been reported to detect a variety of fungal pathogens from blood and pulmonary samples, including Fusarium (121). The same technology was used to type fusaria associated with the 2006 keratitis outbreaks within the U.S. (11). As with other opportunistic fungi, molecular methods such as PCR appear to have promise for the detection and identification of fusaria causing infections; however, the value of these tools in the management of patients remains to be determined.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures
sect1.para: In general,Fusarium species can be recovered easily on routine mycological media without specific growth requirements. Given the aggressive nature of fusaria in neutropenic, immunocompromised individuals, however, the use of a medium for direct plating of specimens that can aid an early diagnosis by displaying consistent morphological features, such as potato dextrose agar (PDA) or potato flake agar (PFA), is highly recommended. Most Fusarium species grow rapidly on PDA or PFA in the absence of cycloheximide, which can be inhibitory. See chapter 118 for detailed information on specimen collection and processing.

sect1.title: Identification
sect1.para: For the limited number ofFusarium species that can be identified using phenotypic data, the microscopic features of phialide shape, number of conidiogenous loci on the conidiogenous cells (i.e., monophialides or polyphialides), formation of conidia in heads or chains, micro- and macroconidial shape and septation, presence and arrangement of chlamydospores, and colony features, including color of colony obverse and reverse (122), are important characters. However, considerable proficiency is required to identify Fusarium isolates to the species level with certainty, and a reference laboratory should be consulted. Although fusaria grow well on most mycological media, the medium can profoundly influence colony morphology, color, and conidium development. Synthetic nutrient agar or water agar with filter paper is widely employed (7). It is important to note that use of rich media such as PDA to maintain isolates can result in cultural degeneration. DNA sequence data in most instances are required to identify clinical Fusarium isolates (118, 123, 124). However, with the wide application of matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) in clinical microbiology laboratories, this technique may allow for the rapid and accurate genus and species complex level identification of Fusarium isolates (125–127). A recently recommended biosafety level (BSL) classification for fusaria is either BSL-1 or BSL-2, depending upon the species (28). Clinical isolates should be handled in a biological safety cabinet.

sect1.title: Typing Systems
sect1.para: As forAspergillus and Candida, multilocus DNA typing (MLST) systems have been developed to identify clinically and veterinary important isolates of Fusarium (55, 57, 128, 129). The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) published a document for identification of bacteria and fungi by DNA sequencing (130), and a consortium of international experts assembled at an ISHAM working group on fungal identification provided clinical laboratories with initial recommendations for molecular typing of Aspergillus, Fusarium, and the Mucorales (131). The internal transcribed spacer region of the nuclear ribosomal DNA (ITS rDNA) guidelines for placing fusaria within an SC are based upon knowledge gained from multilocus sequencing (ITS and nuclear large-subunit [LSU] ribosomal DNA, TEF-1, and second largest subunit of RNA polymerase [RPB2]) analyzed by phylogenetic methods (8–14). These guidelines propose that ITS sequence can be used to place the Fusarium isolate within an SC by using the sequence to conduct BLASTn queries of FUSARIUM-ID v.3.0 and NCBI GenBank. DNA sequence data from some of the loci mentioned above are essential for identification of most clinically important fusaria to the species level (131). In addition to NCBI GenBank, which is a valuable but challenging resource to use because many Fusarium sequences are misidentified (132), FUSARIUM-ID is the only accessible nucleotide sequence database dedicated to identifying fusaria via a downloadable resource (41, 56, 124).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Conventional serologic tests have been used to measure exposure of specific patient populations toFusarium, most commonly in the setting of occupational exposure or indoor dampness problems (133–135). In these populations, immunoglobulin G (IgG) directed against Fusarium can be detected. Elevated levels of IgE and IgG antibody directed against F. oxysporum were found in a patient with allergic bronchopulmonary mycosis due to this pathogen (136). Anti-Fusarium antibodies have not been evaluated as a diagnostic tool for patients with invasive fusariosis. However, as patients with invasive disease are most often immunocompromised, they may not be able to mount an antibody response, making this a less fruitful avenue to explore for diagnostic purposes.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: The typical antifungal susceptibility profiles ofFusarium species are of relative resistance to most antifungal agents (137). The MICs for amphotericin B and triazoles are elevated relative to those seen for Aspergillus species. In vitro studies show relatively high MICs of amphotericin B and itraconazole for members of the FSSC (MIC90s, 4 and >8 μg/ml, respectively) and FOSC (MIC90s, 1.0 and >8 μg/ml, respectively) (138). Universal in vitro resistance was found within clade 3 of the FSSC (139), and testing of this SC by the European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) method indicated a lack of activity by any agent tested (140). Voriconazole, posaconazole, and itraconazole show variable to no in vitro activity against clinical isolates of Fusarium (141, 142). In one series, voriconazole was active against an unidentified member of the FSSC (reported as F. solani), F. oxysporum, F. proliferatum, and F. verticillioides (reported as F. moniliforme) (MIC90, 2 μg/ml) but was not fungicidal against most isolates (143, 144). Although voriconazole and posaconazole exhibit only modest activity in vitro against isolates of Fusarium, these triazoles have been used successfully in some patients with amphotericin B-refractory fusariosis (145–147). Voriconazole is currently the treatment choice in most cases. The newest licensed triazole isavuconazole failed to show good in vitro activity against Fusarium species (148, 149). The echinocandins show no meaningful activity against Fusarium in vitro (150, 151); the fks1 gene appears to confer intrinsic resistance to echinocandins in an unidentified member of the FSSC (152). In vitro testing of rarely encountered Fusarium species in the FFSC, FCSC, and FIESC showed that terbinafine was the most active agent except for a member of the FIESC (reported as F. incarnatum), against which amphotericin B was the most active agent (153, 154). In contrast, terbinafine showed high MIC90s against members of the FSSC and FOSC (155). Synergy studies in a murine model with F. oxysporum showed prolonged survival and reduced fungal burden with a combination of amphotericin B and posaconazole (156); silver nitrate also exhibited in vitro activity against several fusaria from ocular infections (157). Newer antifungals, such as manogepix and olorofim, have good in vitro activity against some Fusarium species and other hyaline molds (158, 159). Due to a lack of correlation between in vitro MIC results and clinical outcomes, the recent ECMM-ISHAM-ASM guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of rare molds do not strongly support antifungal susceptibility testing against Fusarium species with currently available antifungals for the purpose of individual treatment decisions (160).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting Results
sect1.para: Early diagnosis of fusariosis is often key to appropriate management strategies, and recovery of aFusarium should be reported to the clinician long before a final identification is made. With few exceptions, fusaria identified by phenotypic features and/or ITS rDNA sequence data should be reported as members of one of the SCs because they typically do not resolve at the species level.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Other opportunistic hyaline molds known to cause disease of humans and other animals are distributed among numerous genera. A few are homothallic ascomycetes and filamentous basidiomycetes; however, the majority are conidial ascomycetes. Most are hyaline or only lightly pigmented; however, some, likeAcrophialophora, produce colonies that become dark centrally. Others, such as Phialemonium, Phialemoniopsis (161), and Coniochaeta (formerly Lecythophora) (162), have been treated as agents of phaeohyphomycosis but are included here as they are frequently pale in culture. A few coelomycetous genera such as Colletotrichum and Phoma are also included. Unlike the hyphomycetes (conidial ascomycetes), which produce exposed conidiophores, coelomycetes produce conidia within semienclosed or enclosed structures known as acervuli or pycnidia, respectively. Infections caused by coelomycetes are typically acquired as a result of some type of implantation of the fungus following trauma rather than by inhalation (163, 164). While continued molecular characterization is placing many of these fungi within more appropriate phylogenetic classifications, Table 3 provides an overview of the fungi included in this chapter based on their phenotypic features. In keeping with the new International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants, in which dual nomenclature for fungi allowed under Article 59 was abandoned (165), only the most widely accepted anamorph (asexual stage name) or teleomorph (sexual stage name) is used here (Table 3), even though making anamorph and teleomorph connections between them where known is still relevant (42).

sect3.title: Homothallic Ascomycetes
sect3.para: Homothallic (self-fertile) ascomycetes that can reproduce sexually, in part because they possess both mating type idiomorphs (i.e.,MAT1-1 and MAT1-2), include genera that produce cleistothecia (ascomata without openings or ostioles), such as Thermoascus, Aphanoascus, and Cephalotheca; those that produce perithecia (ascomata with ostioles), such as Achaetomium (Fig. 1G), Chaetomium, Microascus (Fig. 2C), and Scopulariopsis; and species whose ascospores are borne in naked clusters, as in Gymnascella. Thermoascus species are non-ostiolate, thermophilic ascomycetes with growth up to 50°C. They produce pale yellow, elliptical, thick-walled ascospores and Paecilomyces-like morphologies. Aphanoascus is a keratinolytic ascomycete characterized by yellowish, lens-shaped reticulate ascospores and Chrysosporium- or Malbranchea-like morphologies. Cephalotheca foveolata is characterized by cleistothecial ascomata covered with yellow to brown hairs, foveolate ascospores (which means that they are delicately pitted or dimpled as seen by scanning electron microscopy; Fig. 2D), and a Phialemonium-like morphology (Fig. 2E) (166). Achaetomium and Chaetomium produce brown, lemon-shaped to fusiform ascospores within ascomata that are ornamented with hairs (or setae), especially around the upper part near the opening, with some species forming Acremonium- or Humicola-like morphologies. Microascus, Scopulariopsis, and related species produce yellowish to reddish orange, variously shaped ascospores extruded in long cirri (like toothpaste squeezed from a tube). Phenotypic identification of species in Microascus is based primarily on perithecial features such as size and length of the necks and ascospore shape. Recent molecular studies on Scopulariopsis and Microascus reveal that they are in separate lineages, with the former being mostly pale in color (except for S. asperula) and the latter being dark. In addition, both genera contain perithecia-forming homothallic species (167–169). Scopulariopsis brevicaulis is the most common species in this annellidic genus (29, 168, 170) (see Fig. 4F). Members of the genus Scopulariopsis are common soil fungi that are noted for their deterioration of cellulosic substrates. Only a few species are reliably reported from human infections, and many are now classified as Microascus based on molecular phylogenetic data (167–169). Gymnascella species produce clusters of ascospores surrounded by yellow or orange filaments, but discrete ascomata are not formed (Fig. 1H and 2A and B).

sect3.title: Schizophyllum and Other Genera
sect3.para: Filamentous basidiomycetes are uncommon causes of human disease and are still poorly characterized. However, those that have been well documented are included in genera that may remain sterile in culture. A clinical isolate may be confirmed as a basidiomycete by the presence of clamp connections on the hyphae, but these diagnostic structures may be lacking. A nonsporulating hyaline mold may be suspected as a basidiomycete when the isolate is fast growing, displays growth on benomyl agar, grows at 37°C, and fails to grow on a medium with cycloheximide (171). A positive urease test result may also suggest basidiomycetous affinities; however, bacterial contamination should always be considered when evaluating positive results.

Schizophyllum commune has long been recognized as a significant cause of allergic sinusitis, allergic bronchopulmonary mycosis, and as an occasional cause of invasive infection in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients (172). Recent molecular characterization of clinical isolates in the genus Schizophyllum has shown that the more common clinical species is S. radiatum rather than S. commune (173). In culture, isolates of either S. radiatum or S. commune may be dikaryotic, producing diagnostic spicules and clamp connections on the hyphae (Fig. 2G), as well as basidiocarps (mushrooms) when incubated under light (Fig. 2H). Other isolates are monokaryotic, remaining sterile, lacking clamps, and sometimes lacking spicules. When spicules are absent, hyphae of Schizophyllum spp. resemble those of Aspergillus species or other molds both in culture and in tissue (171, 174, 175) (Fig. 2F). Monokaryotic isolates are difficult to identify phenotypically, and molecular characterization is necessary for species confirmation (175, 176).

Other uncommon basidiomycetes causing disease in humans and other animals includeTropicoporus tropicalis (formerly Inonotus tropicalis) (Fig. 3A) (177, 178), Rigidoporus (Oxyporus) corticola (179, 180), Emmia (Ceriporia) lacerata (180, 181), Irpex lacteus (182), a Perenniporia sp. (183), Volvariella volvacea (184), Coprinellus/Coprinopsis (Coprinus) species with arthroconidium-forming Hormographiella morphs (185, 186), the Sporothrix-like Quambalaria cyanescens (187) previously reported as Sporothrix cyanescens (176), Cerinosterus cyanescens (188), and Fugomyces cyanescens (34). Another basidiomycete whose pathogenic potential remains to be determined is Phanerochaete chrysosporium (formerly Sporotrichum pruinosum) (189).

sect3.title: Acremonium, Sarocladium, Coniochaeta, Phialemonium, and Phialemoniopsis
sect3.para: Fungi belonging to the generaAcremonium, Sarocladium, Coniochaeta (formerly Lecythophora), and Phialemonium form single-celled conidia in slimy masses or chains from long slender phialides or short, intercalary condiogenous cells referred to as adelophialides. Conidia are also formed from Sporodochium-like masses in Phialemoniopsis. The polyphyletic genus Acremonium, formerly called Cephalosporium, includes approximately 100 species associated with soil, insects, sewage, rhizospheres of plants, and other environmental substrates. Molecular data have provided evidence for the restructuring of the genus along phylogenetic lines (28, 190, 191), and this is currently in progress. The most frequently encountered clinical species in the U.S. include Sarocladium (Acremonium) kiliense and Acremonium egyptiacum, formerly the A. sclerotigenum-A. egyptiacum group (192). A more recent phylogenetic overview of Acremonium and related taxa has placed several clinical species in the genus Sarocladium, e.g., S. kiliense, S. strictum, and S. bacillisporum (193). The genera Brunneomyces and Chordomyces were also recently erected for several unnamed species formerly classified in the genus Acremonium (194). The genus Lecythophora, which contained two clinically significant species, L. hoffmannii and L. mutabilis, was transferred to the genus Coniochaeta based on the name’s priority and in keeping with elimination of dual nomenclature after January 1, 2013. This genus now contains nine species, including C. hoffmannii and C. mutabilis (162). Human etiologic agents in the genus Phialemonium previously included P. obovatum and P. curvatum (28). P. obovatum is retained in the genus, and new species added include P. atrogriseum (Acremonium atrogriseum), P. inflatum (Paecilomyces inflatus), P. globosum, and P. limoniforme (161, 195). However, species that produced Sporodochium-like conidiomata (species previously reported as P. curvatum) were transferred to the genus Phialemoniopsis, which now includes P. curvata, P. pluriloculosa, P. cornearis, P. ocularis, and P. hongkongensis (161). Recently, a study of Thyridium-like sexual morphs were found to produce Phialemoniopsis-like anamorphs. Subsequent phylogenetic analyses revealed that Phialemoniopsis is a synonym of the genus Thyridium and that the familial placement of Phialemoniopsis, Phialemoniopsidaceae, is a synonym of Thyridiaceae in the order Thyridiales. As a consequence, all Phialemoniopsis species were transferred to the genus Thyridium as T. cornearis, T. curvatum, T. endophyticum, T. hongkongense, T. limonesiae, T. pluriloculosum, and T. oculorum (196). As many of these genera are very similar morphologically, identification to the species level is very difficult without molecular data. Thus, many reports of infection are based on unidentified species (15, 191). The genus Phaeoacremonium, including P. parasiticum and some other species associated with human infection, is distinguished from Acremonium by its brownish pigmented hyphae and conidiophores (see chapter 125 of this Manual). The genera Coniochaeta and Phialemonium differ from Acremonium by their formation of short, stumpy phialides without basal septa (called adelophialides) in addition to the more spindle-shaped phialides (197), but these distinctions are not always readily observed. Coniochaeta mutabilis differs from C. hoffmannii in forming brown chlamydospores on sporulation media (162).

sect3.title: Arthrographis, Onychocola, Scytalidium, and Neoscytalidium
sect3.para: The generaArthrographis, Onychocola, Scytalidium, and Neoscytalidium are hyaline and/or dark arthroconidium-forming fungi. Arthrographis kalrae is a rare thermotolerant opportunist recovered from skin, lung, corneal ulcer, and sinus (34, 198, 199). Because initial growth is often yeast-like, an isolate may not be recognized as a pleomorphic mold and thus may be incorrectly subjected to tests commonly used for yeast identification. Additional species include A. curvata, A. longispora, A. chlamydospora, and A. globosa (200). Onychocola canadensis (Fig. 3F and G) is a cycloheximide-tolerant hyphomycete causing nondermatophytic onychomycosis. The teleomorph of Onychocola canadensis is Arachnomyces nodosetosus (201). In keeping with unitary nomenclature, i.e., One Fungus, One Name (1F/1N), Arachnomyces has nomenclatural priority over Onychocola; hence, all Onychocola species are renamed Arachnomyces (202). Scytalidium cuboideum (Arthrographis cuboidea), recently reported from respiratory specimens including a lung mass and a nasal sinus, is differentiated from other species in the genus by its orange colonies and yellow cuboid arthroconidia. Although S. cuboideum is not known to cause disease, growth at 37ºC suggests potential pathogenicity (203). The Neoscytalidium (Scytalidium) dimidiatum complex includes the hyaline mold formerly known as Scytalidium hyalinum, so is also mentioned here (204).

sect3.title: Beauveria and Parengyodontium
sect3.para: Beauveria and Parengyodontium (formerly Engyodontium) species produce solitary conidia borne sympodially. The Beauveria bassiana species complex comprises insect pathogens with limited virulence for humans (205). Parengyodontium album is closely related to (28) and was segregated from Beauveria. Recent molecular studies have shown that Parengyodontium (Engyodontium) album isolates form a monophyletic cluster and are separate from other Engyodontium species; thus, the new genus designation (206).

sect3.title: Chrysosporium, Myceliophthora, Thermothelomyces, Myriodontium, Nannizziopsis, Paranannizziopsis, and Ophidiomyces
sect3.para: Members of the generaChrysosporium (Fig. 3B and C), Myceliophthora, Thermothelomyces, Myriodontium, and Nannizziopsis (Fig. 3E) produce solitary, usually single-celled conidia that are called aleurioconidia because of the lytic method of conidium dehiscence (31). Members of these genera are related to the dermatophytes and the dimorphic pathogens that produce teleomorphs (sexual states), classified in the ascomycete order Onygenales (31, 33) and sharing with them a tolerance to cycloheximide. Myceliophthora was separated into four genera with the most common clinical species now in Thermothelomyces as T. thermophila (formerly M. thermophila) (207). The recently described family within the Onygenales, Nannizziopsidaceae, contains the genera of Nannizziopsis, Paranannizziopsis, and Ophidiomyces (formerly in Chrysosporium) (208, 209).

sect3.title: Metarhizium and Trichoderma
sect3.para: A multilocus phylogenetic analysis of theMetarhizium anisopliae complex, an insect pathogen of wide distribution, revealed that it comprises multiple species-level lineages (210). A taxonomic revision of the genus was made by Driver et al. in 2005 (211), and more recent generic and species boundaries were defined in keeping with IF/IN by Kepler et al. (212, 213). Conidia are produced in chains that adhere together, in contrast to Trichoderma species, which form conidia in slimy heads. Morphological criteria for recognition of the Trichoderma longibrachiatum clade include: (i) fast-growing yellowish-green colonies on potato dextrose agar; (ii) a strong yellow diffusing pigment present at 30°C but absent at 40°C; (iii) hyphae that are sparingly branched and form phialides that are mostly solitary, longer, and more gradually tapered (cylindrical); and (iv) smooth, oblong to ellipsoidal conidia (Fig. 4G and H). Intercalary phialides and chlamydospores are common. An oligonucleotide barcode program, TrichoKEY, was published in 2006 for sequence-based identification (214). Recent molecular studies have elucidated clinically relevant species (215), defined species complexes (216), and provided a list of accepted Trichoderma names (217).

sect3.title: Paecilomyces, Purpureocillium, Acrophialophora, and Rasamsonia
sect3.para: The polyphyletic species ofPaecilomyces occur worldwide as soil saprophytes, insect parasites, and agents of biodeterioration. Recent studies show that the medically significant Paecilomyces variotii (Byssochlamys spectabilis) is actually a complex comprising five species, with P. variotii and P. formosus being the most important clinically (218). Their affinities are within the ascomycete family Trichocomaceae, which also includes Penicillium, Talaromyces, and Aspergillus. The genus Thermoascus (Thermoascaceae) also contains Paecilomyces-like morphologies. The colony (Fig. 3H) and morphological features of the P. variotii complex are described in Table 3. A similar species, P. marquandii, which produces a yellow diffusing pigment and cannot grow at 37°C, has not been documented as an agent of disease (219). It was recently transferred to the genus Metarhizium (212). Purpureocillium is a new genus for the medically important Purpureocillium lilacinum (formerly Paecilomyces lilacinus), now placed within the family Ophiocordycipitaceae (220). Colonies are typically lilac in color, the growth rate is slower than that of Paecilomyces spp., it shows restricted growth at 37ºC, and chlamydospores are absent.

Acrophialophora is a thermotolerant and potentially neurotropic genus widespread in temperate to tropical regions. Colonies are initially pale but darken centrally at maturity. Acrophialophora fusispora was formerly classified as Paecilomyces fusisporus; however, Acrophialophora differs from Paecilomyces by producing unbranched, erect, brown, echinulate conidiophores, which are fertile at the apex and anchored by a foot cell, and basally swollen monophialidic or occasionally polyphialidic conidiogenous cells. Conidia are borne in chains, and distinct spiral bands may be present (221). Members of this genus may superficially resemble Lomentospora (Scedosporium) prolificans (222). Recent molecular studies have shown that the genus includes three species, A. fusispora, A. levis, and A. seudatica, with A. levis being the most common clinically (223).

Rasamsonia is a new genus in the family Trichocomaceae that accommodates thermotolerant or thermophilic species segregated from Geosmithia (224). It is distinguished from Penicillium and Talaromyces species by roughened stipes, metulae, and phialides and by cuneiform to ellipsoidal conidia (Fig. 3D). Rasamsonia argillacea, under the name Geosmithia argillacea, caused a disseminated disease in a German shepherd dog (225) and is an emerging agent in cystic fibrosis patients (226) and those with chronic granulomatous disease (227). Phylogenetic studies of the genus have differentiated this genus into 12 species, and several members, including those of the R. argillacea species complex (R. argillacea sensu stricto, R. aegroticola, R. piperina, and R. eburnea) are clinically important (228, 229).

sect2.title: Coelomycetous Fungi (Fruiting Body-Forming Conidial Ascomycetes)
sect2.para: Coelomycetous fungi are being documented as agents of disease more frequently, particularly in patients maintained on long-term immunosuppressive therapy. Infections are typically acquired through some type of direct implantation of the fungus, in contrast to inhalation as in the hyphomycetous genera. Two of the more common genera addressed here includeColletotrichum and Phoma; however, a review of the recent taxonomic revisions of the many genera is beyond the scope of this chapter (230–233). Colletotrichum species are acervular coelomycetes occasionally recovered as agents of disease. They produce fast-growing colonies of various shades that are most easily recognized in the laboratory by the production of brown, variably shaped appressoria. Honey-colored masses of conidia may be present in culture as well as setae and sclerotia in some species. Cano and colleagues (234) described the salient features observed in clinical strains. Studies are currently ongoing to resolve cryptic species (235). Species in the genus Phoma are pycnidial coelomycetes that may be pale or darker in culture. They are usually recognized by small dark pycnidia that form on the surface or are immersed in the agar. Boerema and colleagues (236) published a Phoma identification manual; however, species differentiation is best handled in a reference laboratory. Two recent reviews of coelomycetous fungi seen in clinical laboratories cite several species that are documented to cause disease, give salient features for their phenotypic identification, and provide in vitro antifungal susceptibility data for selected genera/species (237, 238). Also see chapter 125 for additional coelomycetous genera.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: The methods of transmission and sources of infection for the other opportunistic hyaline molds are like those seen in aspergillosis and fusariosis, and acquisition is typically through inhalation or traumatic implantation. Coelomycetous fungi, although ubiquitous, are mostly reported from cases of keratitis and subcutaneous mycoses in compromised individuals (239) and appear to be acquired primarily through external inoculation (163).

sect3.title: Homothallic Ascomycetes
sect3.para: Species ofChaetomium, Amesia, and Achaetomium (Fig. 1G) are neurotropic agents causing cerebral infections (47, 48, 240), while Chaetomium globosum occurs most commonly as a contaminant or as a rare agent of onychomycosis (6, 34). Microascus spp. are also agents of deep infections, including endocarditis (241) and a brain abscess (242) by Microascus cinereus, disseminated infections by M. cirrosus, and a fatal pneumonia by M. trigonosporus (243). Scopulariopsis brevicaulis (Fig. 4F) and other species are occasional agents of onychomycosis (31, 33, 170). They are also rarely invasive, causing otomycosis, keratitis, prosthetic valve endocarditis, sinusitis, pneumonia, brain abscess, and subcutaneous and bone invasion in immunocompetent and immunosuppressed individuals (28, 244–249). Scopulariopsis candida and S. acremonium (now Acaulium acremonium) have been reported from invasive sinusitis, but few details concerning the latter species were provided in the report (250, 251). Brain abscesses were reported to be caused by Yunnania carbonaria (formerly Fuscoannellis carbonaria and Scopulariopsis carbonaria) (252), Microascus croci, or M. paisii (all formerly known as S. brumptii, but S. brumptii is now under the name of Microascus paisii) (167). Microascus paisii differs from M. croci by its dark gray or black colonies and its ability to grow and sporuate well at 37°C (168). Invasive cutaneous infections caused by Microascus cirrosus have been reported to occur in liver transplant and bone marrow recipients (245, 253). A case of fatal S. acremonium (now Acaulium acremonium) infection was reported to occur in a lung transplant recipient (254). Numerous other species recovered from mostly respiratory specimens with growth at 37 to 40°C, though not substantiated as etiologic agents, are noted in recent publications (167–169). Additional rarely implicated genera include Gymnascella (Fig. 1H and 2A and B) and Cephalotheca (Fig. 2D and E). Please see references 28, 241–243, 245, 255, and 256.

sect3.title: Schizophyllum and Other Genera
sect3.para: Filamentous basidiomycetes, as well as species of smuts that may appear yeast-like (Ustilaginaceae and Tilletiaceae), are commonly isolated from respiratory specimens and sometimes from blood; however, their significance can be difficult to evaluate (171, 257).

Schizophyllum radiatum is recognized as a significant cause of allergy-related sinusitis and pulmonary disease, including allergic bronchopulmonary mycosis and bronchial mucoid impaction (171, 174, 175, 258–261) as well as infections of the brain, lungs, and buccal mucosa in both immunocompetent and immunosuppressed patients (34, 171, 260, 262, 263). Coprinopsis cinerea (formerly Coprinus cinereus) has been reported under its anamorph name (264), Hormographiella aspergillata, from prosthetic valve endocarditis, fatal lung infections in leukemic patients, a lung abscess in a patient with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, keratomycosis in a dog, and cutaneous lesions (34, 185, 186, 265, 266). Tropicoporus tropicalis (formerly Inonotus tropicalis) was reported as an agent of osteomyelitis in a patient with X-linked chronic granulomatous disease (177, 178) and another patient with this disease (D. Sutton, unpublished data). Emmia (Ceriporia) lacerata was reported in four cases from pulmonary sites (181), Irpex lacteus was recovered from a pulmonary abscess in an immunosuppressed child (182), a Perenniporia sp. was the etiologic agent in a pulmonary fungal ball (183), and Volvariella volvacea incited invasive disease and death in a Hodgkin’s lymphoma patient (184). The Sporothrix-like organism Quambalaria cyanescens was reported in an augmentation mammoplasty (267). See Chowdhary et al. for a recent review of basidiomycetous fungi and human disease (172).

sect3.title: Acremonium, Sarocladium, Coniochaeta, Phialemonium, and Phialemoniopsis
sect3.para: Many reports concerningAcremonium involve infections of the nail, skin, or eye or mycetoma (see also Chapter 126) (28, 31); however, many of these species are now classified in other genera. Localized and disseminated infections have been reported in patients following valve replacement, dialysis, or transplantation or in patients with hematologic or solid-organ malignancies (6, 15, 28, 191, 268, 269). Fungemia is common. Several cases of invasive Sarocladium (Acremonium) strictum have been reported (270–272). Coniochaeta (Lecythophora) mutabilis was reported to cause prosthetic valve endocarditis in a diabetic patient (273), and C. hoffmannii was reported to cause chronic sinusitis in an HIV-infected patient (274). Phialemonium obovatum was an agent of endocarditis (275). Thyridium hongkongense (Phialemoniopsis hongkongensis) was identified in a subcutaneous nodule in a patient with underlying liver cirrhosis (276), and arthritis, fungemia, endovascular infections, and ophthalmitis have been reported for Thyridium curvatum (formerly Phialemonium curvatum and Phialemoniopsis curvata) (277–280).

sect3.title: Arthrographis, Onychocola, Scytalidium, and Neoscytalidium
sect3.para: The thermotolerantArthrographis kalrae is a rare opportunist recovered from skin, lung, corneal ulcer, and sinus (34, 198, 199). Arachnomyces nodosetosus (Onychocola canadensis) (Fig. 3F and G) causes distal subungual nondermatophytic onychomycosis or, less commonly, white superficial onychomycosis and infection of the glabrous skin (31, 33, 201, 281). Although A. nodosetosus (O. canadensis) is a relatively uncommon agent of onychomyosis, more than 60 isolates from nails have been recorded from New Zealand, Australia, Europe, and the United States, with two additional cases from Spain (282). Growth of Scytalidium cuboideum (Anthrographis cuboidea) at 37°C suggests its pathogenic potential (203).
