sect3.title: Beauveria and Parengyodontium
sect3.para: Beauveria bassiana has caused several cases of fungal keratitis (283, 284). A recent molecular study comparing clinical keratitis isolates with Environmental Protection Agency-registered strains showed that these strains were unrelated (285, 286). An isolate that failed to grow at 35°C also caused disseminated disease in a patient with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (44). Parengyodontium (Engyodontium) album was the cause of two cases of endocarditis (287), one of which occurred in a bovine valve replacement (206).

sect3.title: Chrysosporium, Myceliophthora, Thermothelomyces, Myriodontium, Nannizziopsis, Paranannizziopsis, and Ophidiomyces
sect3.para: The thermotolerantChrysosporium zonatum is an etiologic agent of human pneumonia and osteomyelitis (288) (Fig. 3B and C). In a review of human infections caused by Chrysosporium, it was reported that they typically occur in immunocompromised individuals (289). The thermophilic species Thermothelomyces (Myceliophthora) thermophila (Fig. 3E) (207) has been reported to cause fatal aortic vasculitis in two patients. It was isolated from the brain of a patient who developed a bacterial cerebral abscess after trauma and severe osteomyelitis following a pitchfork injury (290–293). The Chrysosporium anamorphs (conidial states) of the Nannizziopsis vriesii complex, also known as CANV and C. ophidioiicola (238), have been transferred to Nannizziopsis, Paranannizziopsis, and Ophidiomyces. Nannizziopsis hominis appears to be a human-associated species (294).

sect3.title: Metarhizium and Trichoderma Species
sect3.para: TheMetarhizium anisopliae complex contains multiple phylogenetically distinct species that are widely distributed insect pathogens. They are also documented to cause keratitis, sinusitis, invasive infections, and disseminated skin lesions (295–298). Species of Trichoderma in section Longibrachiatum, which includes T. longibrachiatum (Fig. 4G and H) and T. citrinoviride, appear to be the most important pathogenic species (299–302). A review of 73 clinical isolates has advanced our understanding of species recovered in a clinical setting, including the new species Trichoderma bissettii (215).

sect3.title: Paecilomyces, Purpureocillium, Acrophialophora, and Rasamsonia
sect3.para: Mycoses caused byPaecilomyces variotii and Purpureocillium lilacinum include cutaneous, subcutaneous, and pulmonary infections, pyelonephritis, sinusitis, cellulitis, endocarditis, and fungemia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients (6, 15, 28, 303–305). The clinical manifestations, treatment options, and outcomes for P. lilacinum infections have been reviewed (306, 307). The species has also been noted to reside in water distribution systems, including those of a bone marrow transplant unit (220). Species within Acrophialophora cause keratitis (253) and pulmonary infections (253, 254), colonize patients with cystic fibrosis (255, 256), and caused a brain abscess in a child with leukemia (221). A recent molecular reevaluation confirms that the genus includes three species: A. fusispora (conspecific with A. nainiana and Masoniella indica), A. levis, and A. seudatica (Ampullifera seudatica), with A. levis being the most common clinically (223). Rasamsonia argillacea (formerly Geosmithia argillacea) has been described as an emerging cause of invasive fungal infection in human chronic granulomatous disease (227, 308) and has also been reported to cause a pulmonary and aortic graft infection in an immune-competent patient (309). It is now considered a species complex comprising R. argillacea sensu stricto, R. piperina, R. aegroticola, and R. eburnea (228), with R. aegroticola being the most common species to colonize airways of cystic fibrosis patients (310). It has been reported to cause a fatal disseminated fungal infection in a cystic fibrosis patient post lung transplantation (311).

sect2.title: Coelomycetous Fungi (Fruiting Body-Forming Conidial Ascomycetes)
sect2.para: Colletotrichum species are primarily phytopathogens but occasionally are recovered as agents of keratitis (28). There are also rare reports of subcutaneous infection following trauma (239). A case of phaeohyphomycotic cysts caused by Phoma species was reported in a patient (312). Numerous other genera are being recovered from clinical specimens, and reviews of these from the U.S. (238) and France (237) have been reported.

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: Methods of collection, transport, and storage of specimens are detailed inChapter 115. As with other invasive mycoses, infections are difficult to diagnose and usually require a combination of clinical, culture, and radiographic findings. Recovery from a normally sterile site and microscopic evidence of invasive growth in tissue provide the most convincing evidence of disease.

sect2.title: Microscopy
sect2.para: Histopathological findings for most opportunistic hyaline molds, including species ofAspergillus, Fusarium, and Scedosporium (Pseudallescheria), are typically indistinguishable (104, 248). Ascospores may occasionally be observed, as was demonstrated with Gymnascella (255), and clamp connections may also be present in tissue sections with Schizophyllum commune (262). Budding forms are rarely observed (103, 268, 269).

sect2.title: Antigen Detection
sect2.para: Detection of (1→3)-β-D-glucan (108, 110) in patients with invasive hyalohyphomycosis may assist with an early diagnosis, but monitoring of this marker needs to be combined with clinical examination of the patient and other diagnostic procedures, such as high-resolution computed tomography scanning. This assay is not specific to any one hyaline mold, and false positives can occur, as previously described.

sect2.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect2.para: Nucleic acid detection has the potential to detect a variety of hyaline molds directly in clinical samples, but its application in clinical diagnosis is still limited. Luminex microbead hybridization technology has been reported to detect a variety of fungal pathogens from clinical blood and pulmonary samples (121). This method appears to have promise for the early detection and identification of various invasive fungal pathogens.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures
sect1.para: Opportunistic hyaline molds are usually cultured easily on routine mycological media, and there are no specific growth requirements; however, media with and without cycloheximide should be employed. The fungicide benomyl at a final concentration of 10 mg/ml in the culture medium has shown utility in distinguishing filamentous basidiomycetes, which are tolerant to benomyl, from ascomycetes, which may be susceptible to this fungicide (313). Coelomycetous fungi (fruiting body-forming conidial ascomycetes) grow well on most fungal media; however, they are notorious for remaining sterile without extended incubation (up to several weeks for some genera) (163). See chapters 115 and 116 for detailed information on appropriate media for initial plating and isolation.

sect1.title: Identification
sect1.para: More detailed descriptions of these hyaline fungi are found in several identification manuals and in the references cited therein (26, 28–36). Many can be identified to the genus level with little difficulty; however, identification of most clinically relevant molds to the species level requires DNA sequence data. Furthermore, MALDI-TOF MS has the potential to speed up genus- and species-level identifications (125). See Table 3 for salient phenotypic features of the organisms reviewed. The use of DNA sequence data to identify isolates that remain sterile in culture is largely dependent on the accuracy of and interpretation of data in publicly accessible databases such as NCBI GenBank (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/genbank/), MycoBank (https://www.mycobank.org/), and FUSARIUM-ID v.3.0 for Fusarium. Unlike NCBI GenBank, sequences in FUSARIUM-ID are rigorously checked for taxonomic accuracy. The validity of this approach was demonstrated by DNA sequence-based identification of several nonsporulating molds (314); this approach will continue to be used more widely.

sect1.title: Typing Systems
sect1.para: Although comparative sequence analysis of clinical isolates is becoming more common in large tertiary-care and research centers, it is far from standardized. Various methods of DNA extraction are available (315), and several different genes or portions thereof may be sequenced (8–14, 17, 67, 130, 131, 316, 317). It should be highlighted, however, that numerous database entries in public databases are incorrect, making comparative sequence analysis without phenotypic correlation a challenge that requires that the top sequence matches be examined critically (131). On the other hand, molecular characterization has become the “gold standard” for classification of species for taxonomic categorization and will continue to provide a better understanding of the evolutionary relationships of clinically significant fungi (8–14, 67, 318). Furthermore, whole-genome sequencing technology could become a new standard for fungal genome typing, as demonstrated in a recent study determining the source of a multinational outbreak of bloodstream infections caused by the fungus Sarocladium kiliense (319).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Serologic procedures currently have little clinical utility in the diagnosis of uncommon hyaline opportunistic fungi.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: Uncommon hyaline molds display various antifungal susceptibility patterns. Susceptibility testing of uncommon molds is useful for empirical antifungal therapy; however, isolates should be assessed individually for appropriate patient management. For publishedin vitro data, see references relating to the genera of interest. Chaetomium infections that failed to respond to treatment with amphotericin B alone or in combination with itraconazole have been reported (320). Voriconazole and the experimental triazoles ravuconazole and albaconazole showed potent activity in vitro against Chaetomium spp., with MICs less than 0.5 μg/ml (320); however, the echinocandin micafungin was not active in vitro. Evaluation of antifungal activitiy against 44 clinical isolates of filamentous basidiomycetous fungi, including Schizophyllum commune (n = 5), Coprinus spp. (n = 8), Bjerkandera adusta (n = 14), and sterile, uncharacterized basidiomycetes (n = 17), demonstrated low MICs for amphotericin B, itraconazole, voriconazole, and posaconazole, in contrast to those of fluconazole and flucytosine (321). No statistically significant differences among the genera were noted.

Antifungals, including amphotericin B and itraconazole, have limitedin vitro activity against Scopulariopsis and Microascus spp., and conflicting results have been reported for voriconazole and terbinafine (155, 322, 323). A promising interaction was observed between terbinafine and fluconazole, itraconazole, and voriconazole in vitro against isolates of S. brevicaulis, although clinical experience with combination therapy is very limited (324). Purpureocillium lilacinum is intrinsically resistant to polyenes, including amphotericin B. When evaluated by the EUCAST and CLSI methods (140, 148, 325), amphotericin B, itraconazole, and the echinocandins showed poor activity against P. lilacinum; however, the extended-spectrum triazoles voriconazole, posaconazole, and isavuconazole and the allylamine terbinafine have deomonstrated good in vitro activity. In contrast, low MICs were obtained for all of the agents listed above for 31 strains of P. variotii, except for voriconazole and ravuconazole (326). There are very limited data on in vitro activity of isavuconazole against uncommon hyaline molds. In one study, no activity or very limited activity was observed against S. kiliense and P. lilacinum, respectively (327). Similarly, members of the Rasamsonia argillacea species complex are intrinsically resistant to both isavuconazole and voriconazole and typically have reduced susceptibility (i.e., elevated MICs) to other extended-spectrum azoles (228, 328).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: The early diagnosis of invasive hyalohyphomycosis caused by fusaria and other hyaline molds is often key to appropriate management strategies. Identification of uncommon hyaline molds should always be evaluated considering the patient’s immune status as well as the anatomic site of recovery and frequency of isolation.
